title: BpS Descriptions and Models
text:
Downloading and understanding BpS descriptions and models

going over a BpS document is a great way to not only help people understand BpS, but also to introduce spatial datasets:

BpS
EVT though s-class rule table (where we get lifeform)
EVC and EVH-rule table
S-class–look at succession class descriptions to understand what “A” means in an addtional way (in addtion to s-class table)

demo downloading BpS descriptions
describe key features/sections of document
link to Blankenship et al 2021
set folks up to explore BpS models (link to veg modeling page, etc.)

title: Downloading LANDFIRE Data
text:
LANDFIRE provides three ways to download spatial data:

Using the LANDFIRE Map Viewer
Downloading CONUS, Hawaii, Alaska or insular area-wide data
Streaming the data with a webservice

Additionally, Mark Buckner has created the rlandfire package, which allows for direct downloading of LANDFIRE data into an R environment.
For this tutorial we will use option 1, downloading data via the LANDFIRE Map Viewer (LMV).

title: Downloading LANDFIRE Data
text:
Using the LANDFIRE Map Viewer

For those inclined to follow videos, we have these on YouTube:

Video one
Video two



For those more inclined to follow screenshots:

Definitely need to resize photos, etc., but here is the basic code for inserting a slideshow (aka ’slickr”).
Also, we may want to reorganize. Currently the set up is:

code for the slickrs are in the “slickr_code” directory
images are in subdirectories within the ‘images’ directory

I used R-Studio’s export tool, clicking the “Export as webpage” button, then exporting to the root directory. We may be able to change this

 Click through the slides for the steps we use to download data using the LMV:

title: Explore in ArcGIS Pro
text: Initial LANDFIRE data exploration in ArcGIS pro – Limited text outlining what users will do on this page – Slider with screenshots demonstrating how to bring in and symbolize one ‘categorical’ dataset (e.g., Biophysical Settings) – Limited text explaining challenges and strategies when working with ’continuous’dataset (sorta, e.g., Existing Vegetation Cover) – Slider demonstrating how to work with continuous dataset – Limited text about making maps, highlighting Sarah’s videos on Universal Design (all three) – Quick guidance on how to explore and export attribute table Do we go into clipping/batch clipping? Adding other map layers? What else do they need to know on this page?

title: Assessning a landscape with LANDFIRE data: a beginner’s guide
text:
LANDFIRE products are extremely useful for natural resource managers, allowing users to complete many tasks, including these that are featured in this website:



Historical ecosystems map.



Mapping and quantifying historical ecosystems (see map below made with LANDFIRE’s Biophysical Settings data)
Mapping and quantifying existing vegetation type, height and cover
Comparing reference and current amounts of ecosystem succession classes

While useful, effectively working with LANDFIRE products can be intimidating due to terminology, GIS processing and data wrangling often required.
Additionally, the “fire-hose” of information can pose a problem. Where is a user to start?

title: Assessning a landscape with LANDFIRE data: a beginner’s guide

While useful, effectively working with LANDFIRE products can be intimidating due to terminology, GIS processing and data wrangling often required.
Additionally, the “fire-hose” of information can pose a problem. Where is a user to start?

title: Assessning a landscape with LANDFIRE data: a beginner’s guide
text:
Goals
Often a good way to start learning something is to jump in and take on a meaningful project. Here we show you how to take a shapefile of your area of interest, then:

Download and process multiple LANDFIRE datasets
Bring LANDFIRE data into ArcGIS pro, explore ways to make maps that follow Universal Design principles (i.e., easier for everyone to read)
Quantify and make charts of attributes of interest
Understand the basics of Biophysical Settings and Models

title: Assessning a landscape with LANDFIRE data: a beginner’s guide
text:
Prerequsites

The following software

ArcGIS pro, and basic abilities (e.g., starting a project, bringing in data)
Microsoft Excel (or similar) and/or R and R-Studio
SyncroSim
Microsoft word (or similar)



Other

A shapefile of your area of interest
Internet access
Space to store data
X# hours
